column1: Many statisticians, including [[Nate Silver]], have argued that data science is not a new field, but rather another name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Nate Silver: What I need from statisticians
column6: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> Others argue that data science is distinct from statistics because it focuses on problems and techniques unique to digital data.<ref>{{Cite web

column12: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> [[Vasant Dhar]] writes that statistics emphasizes quantitative data and description. In contrast, data science deals with quantitative and qualitative data (e.g., from images, text, sensors, transactions, customer information, etc.) and emphasizes prediction and action.<ref>{{Cite journal
column23: url=http://archive.nyu.edu/handle/2451/31553 }}</ref> [[Andrew Gelman]] of [[Columbia University]] has described statistics as a non-essential part of data science.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Stanford professor [[David Donoho]] writes that data science is not distinguished from statistics by the size of datasets or use of computing and that many graduate programs misleadingly advertise their analytics and statistics training as the essence of a data-science program. He describes data science as an applied field growing out of traditional statistics.<ref name="":7"" />
In 1962, [[John Tukey]] described a field he called ""[[data analysis]]"", which resembles modern data science.<ref name="":7"">{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In 1985, in a lecture given to the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, [[C. F. Jeff Wu]] used the term ""data science"" for the first time as an alternative name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite journal
column9: title=Future directions of statistical research in China: a historical perspective
column16: access-date=29 November 2020}}</ref> Later, attendees at a 1992 statistics symposium at the [[Montpellier 2 University
column17: University of Montpellier  II]] acknowledged the emergence of a new discipline focused on data of various origins and forms, combining established concepts and principles of statistics and data analysis with computing.<ref>{{Cite book
column35: title=The Development of Data Science: Implications for Education, Employment, Research, and the Data Revolution for Sustainable Development

column1: The term ""data science"" has been traced back to 1974, when [[Peter Naur]] proposed it as an alternative name to computer science.<ref name="":2"" /> In 1996, the International Federation of Classification Societies became the first conference to specifically feature data science as a topic.<ref name="":2"" /> However, the definition was still in flux. After the 1985 lecture at the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, in 1997 [[C. F. Jeff Wu]] again suggested that statistics should be renamed data science. He reasoned that a new name would help statistics shed inaccurate stereotypes, such as being synonymous with accounting or limited to describing data.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In 1998, Hayashi Chikio argued for data science as a new, interdisciplinary concept, with three aspects: data design, collection, and analysis.<ref name=""Murtagh 2018 14""/>

column1: During the 1990s, popular terms for the process of finding patterns in datasets (which were increasingly large) included ""knowledge discovery"" and ""[[data mining]]"".<ref name="":2"" /><ref name="":1"">{{Cite web
column3: title=A Very Short History of Data Science

column1: In 2012, technologists [[Thomas H. Davenport]] and [[DJ Patil]] declared ""Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century"",<ref>{{cite magazine
column5: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
column8: access-date=2022-10-10}}</ref> a catchphrase that was picked up even by major-city newspapers like the [[New York Times]]<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Data Science: The Numbers of Our Lives
column20: title=Behind the scenes of the 'sexiest job of the 21st century'
column24: access-date=2022-10-10}}</ref> A decade later, they reaffirmed it, stating that ""the job is more in demand than ever with employers"".<ref>{{cite magazine
column28: title=Is Data Scientist Still the Sexiest Job of the 21st Century?

column1: The modern conception of data science as an independent discipline is sometimes attributed to [[William S. Cleveland]].<ref>{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In a 2001 paper, he advocated an expansion of statistics beyond theory into technical areas; because this would significantly change the field, it warranted a new name.<ref name="":1"" /> ""Data science"" became more widely used in the next few years: in 2002, the [[Committee on Data for Science and Technology]] launched the ''Data Science Journal''. In 2003, Columbia University launched ''The Journal of Data Science''.<ref name="":1"" /> In 2014, the [[American Statistical Association]]'s Section on Statistical Learning and Data Mining changed its name to the Section on Statistical Learning and Data Science, reflecting the ascendant popularity of data science.<ref>{{Cite news
column11: title=ASA Expands Scope, Outreach to Foster Growth, Collaboration in Data Science
column14: publisher=[[American Statistical Association]]}}. In 2013 the first European Conference on Data Analysis (ECDA2013) started in Luxembourg the process which founded the European Association for Data Science (EuADS) www.euads.org in Luxembourg in 2015. </ref>

column1: The professional title of ""data scientist"" has been attributed to [[DJ Patil]] and [[Jeff Hammerbacher]] in 2008.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
column12: issn=0017-8012}}</ref> Though it was used by the [[National Science Board]] in their 2005 report ""Long-Lived Digital Data Collections: Enabling Research and Education in the 21st Century"", it referred broadly to any key role in managing a digital [[data collection]].<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=US NSF â€“ NSB-05-40, Long-Lived Digital Data Collections Enabling Research and Education in the 21st Century

column15: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> Data scientists are responsible for breaking down big data into usable information and creating software and algorithms that help companies and organizations determine optimal operations.<ref name="":6"">{{Cite web

column1: Data science and data analysis are both important disciplines in the field of [[data management]] and analysis, but they differ in several key ways. While both fields involve working with data, data science is more of an [[interdisciplinary field]] that involves the application of statistical, computational, and [[machine learning]] methods to extract insights from data and make predictions, while data analysis is more focused on the examination and interpretation of data to identify patterns and trends.<ref name="":8"">{{Cite book
column2: title=An Introduction to Statistical Learning: with Applications in R.
column19: title=Data Science for Business: What You Need to Know about Data Mining and Data-Analytic Thinking.

column1: Data analysis typically involves working with smaller, structured datasets to answer specific questions or solve specific problems. This can involve tasks such as [[data cleaning]], [[data visualization]], and exploratory data analysis to gain insights into the data and develop hypotheses about relationships between [[variable (research)
column2: variables]]. Data analysts typically use statistical methods to test these hypotheses and draw conclusions from the data. For example, a [[data analyst]] might analyze sales data to identify trends in customer behavior and make recommendations for marketing strategies.<ref name="":8"" />

column1: Data science, on the other hand, is a more complex and [[iterative]] process that involves working with larger, more complex datasets that often require advanced computational and statistical methods to analyze. Data scientists often work with [[unstructured data]] such as text or images and use [[machine learning]] algorithms to build predictive models and make data-driven decisions. In addition to [[statistical analysis]], data science often involves tasks such as [[data preprocessing]], [[feature engineering]], and model selection. For instance, a data scientist might develop a recommendation system for an e-commerce platform by analyzing user behavior patterns and using [[machine learning algorithms]] to predict user preferences.<ref name="":9"" /><ref name="":10"">{{Cite book

While data analysis focuses on extracting insights from existing data, data science goes beyond that by incorporating the development and implementation of predictive models to make informed decisions. Data scientists are often responsible for collecting and cleaning data, selecting appropriate analytical techniques, and deploying models in real-world scenarios. They work at the intersection of mathematics, [[computer science]], and [[domain expertise]] to solve complex problems and uncover hidden patterns in large datasets.<ref name="":9"" />
Despite these differences, data science and data analysis are closely related fields and often require similar skill sets. Both fields require a solid foundation in statistics, [[Computer programming
column2: programming]], and [[data visualization]], as well as the ability to communicate findings effectively to both technical and non-technical audiences. Both fields benefit from [[critical thinking]] and [[domain knowledge]], as understanding the context and nuances of the data is essential for accurate analysis and modeling.<ref name="":8"" /><ref name="":9"" />

column1: In summary, data analysis and data science are distinct yet interconnected disciplines within the broader field of [[data management]] and analysis. Data analysis focuses on extracting insights and drawing conclusions from [[structured data]], while data science involves a more comprehensive approach that combines [[statistical analysis]], computational methods, and [[machine learning]] to extract insights, build predictive models, and drive data-driven [[decision-making]]. Both fields use data to understand patterns, make informed decisions, and solve complex problems across various domains.
[[File:Cloud computing in enabling data science at scale.jpg
column3: A cloud-based architecture for enabling big data analytics. Data flows from various sources, such as [[Personal computer
column6: smart phones]], through cloud services for processing and analysis, finally leading to various [[big data]] applications.]]

column1: [[Cloud computing]] can offer access to large amounts of computational power and [[Data storage

column22: doi=10.1016/j.is.2014.07.006}}</ref> In [[big data]], where volumes of information are continually generated and processed, these platforms can be used to handle complex and resource-intensive analytical tasks.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite journal
column34: title=A survey of machine learning for big data processing
column35: journal=EURASIP Journal on Advances in Signal Processing

column1: Some distributed computing frameworks are designed to handle big data workloads. These frameworks can enable data scientists to process and analyze large datasets in parallel, which can reducing processing times.<ref name="":3"">{{Cite book
column24: chapter=Spark SQL: Relational Data Processing in Spark
column26: title=Proceedings of the 2015 ACM SIGMOD International Conference on Management of Data

column1: Data science involve collecting, processing, and analyzing data which often including personal and sensitive information. Ethical concerns include potential privacy violations, bias perpetuation, and negative societal impacts <ref name="":4"">{{Cite journal

column25: title=The Ethics of Big Data: Current and Foreseeable Issues in Biomedical Contexts

column1: Many statisticians, including [[Nate Silver]], have argued that data science is not a new field, but rather another name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Nate Silver: What I need from statisticians
column6: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> Others argue that data science is distinct from statistics because it focuses on problems and techniques unique to digital data.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=What's the Difference Between Data Science and Statistics?
column12: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> [[Vasant Dhar]] writes that statistics emphasizes quantitative data and description. In contrast, data science deals with quantitative and qualitative data (e.g., from images, text, sensors, transactions, customer information, etc.) and emphasizes prediction and action.<ref>{{Cite journal
column23: url=http://archive.nyu.edu/handle/2451/31553 }}</ref> [[Andrew Gelman]] of [[Columbia University]] has described statistics as a non-essential part of data science.<ref>{{Cite web
column25: title=Statistics is the least important part of data science Â« Statistical Modeling, Causal Inference, and Social Science

column1: Stanford professor [[David Donoho]] writes that data science is not distinguished from statistics by the size of datasets or use of computing and that many graduate programs misleadingly advertise their analytics and statistics training as the essence of a data-science program. He describes data science as an applied field growing out of traditional statistics.<ref name="":7"" />
In 1962, [[John Tukey]] described a field he called ""[[data analysis]]"", which resembles modern data science.<ref name="":7"">{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In 1985, in a lecture given to the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, [[C. F. Jeff Wu]] used the term ""data science"" for the first time as an alternative name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite journal
column9: title=Future directions of statistical research in China: a historical perspective
column16: access-date=29 November 2020}}</ref> Later, attendees at a 1992 statistics symposium at the [[Montpellier 2 University
column17: University of Montpellier  II]] acknowledged the emergence of a new discipline focused on data of various origins and forms, combining established concepts and principles of statistics and data analysis with computing.<ref>{{Cite book
column35: title=The Development of Data Science: Implications for Education, Employment, Research, and the Data Revolution for Sustainable Development

column1: The term ""data science"" has been traced back to 1974, when [[Peter Naur]] proposed it as an alternative name to computer science.<ref name="":2"" /> In 1996, the International Federation of Classification Societies became the first conference to specifically feature data science as a topic.<ref name="":2"" /> However, the definition was still in flux. After the 1985 lecture at the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, in 1997 [[C. F. Jeff Wu]] again suggested that statistics should be renamed data science. He reasoned that a new name would help statistics shed inaccurate stereotypes, such as being synonymous with accounting or limited to describing data.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In 1998, Hayashi Chikio argued for data science as a new, interdisciplinary concept, with three aspects: data design, collection, and analysis.<ref name=""Murtagh 2018 14""/>

column1: During the 1990s, popular terms for the process of finding patterns in datasets (which were increasingly large) included ""knowledge discovery"" and ""[[data mining]]"".<ref name="":2"" /><ref name="":1"">{{Cite web
column3: title=A Very Short History of Data Science

column1: In 2012, technologists [[Thomas H. Davenport]] and [[DJ Patil]] declared ""Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century"",<ref>{{cite magazine
column5: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
column8: access-date=2022-10-10}}</ref> a catchphrase that was picked up even by major-city newspapers like the [[New York Times]]<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Data Science: The Numbers of Our Lives
column20: title=Behind the scenes of the 'sexiest job of the 21st century'
column24: access-date=2022-10-10}}</ref> A decade later, they reaffirmed it, stating that ""the job is more in demand than ever with employers"".<ref>{{cite magazine
column28: title=Is Data Scientist Still the Sexiest Job of the 21st Century?

column1: The modern conception of data science as an independent discipline is sometimes attributed to [[William S. Cleveland]].<ref>{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In a 2001 paper, he advocated an expansion of statistics beyond theory into technical areas; because this would significantly change the field, it warranted a new name.<ref name="":1"" /> ""Data science"" became more widely used in the next few years: in 2002, the [[Committee on Data for Science and Technology]] launched the ''Data Science Journal''. In 2003, Columbia University launched ''The Journal of Data Science''.<ref name="":1"" /> In 2014, the [[American Statistical Association]]'s Section on Statistical Learning and Data Mining changed its name to the Section on Statistical Learning and Data Science, reflecting the ascendant popularity of data science.<ref>{{Cite news
column11: title=ASA Expands Scope, Outreach to Foster Growth, Collaboration in Data Science
column14: publisher=[[American Statistical Association]]}}. In 2013 the first European Conference on Data Analysis (ECDA2013) started in Luxembourg the process which founded the European Association for Data Science (EuADS) www.euads.org in Luxembourg in 2015. </ref>

column1: The professional title of ""data scientist"" has been attributed to [[DJ Patil]] and [[Jeff Hammerbacher]] in 2008.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
column12: issn=0017-8012}}</ref> Though it was used by the [[National Science Board]] in their 2005 report ""Long-Lived Digital Data Collections: Enabling Research and Education in the 21st Century"", it referred broadly to any key role in managing a digital [[data collection]].<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=US NSF â€“ NSB-05-40, Long-Lived Digital Data Collections Enabling Research and Education in the 21st Century

column1: There is still no consensus on the definition of data science, and it is considered by some to be a [[buzzword]].<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Data Science: What's The Half-Life of a Buzzword?
column8: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> [[Big data]] is a related marketing term.<ref name="":5"">{{Cite web
column10: title=The Impacts of Big Data That You May Not Have Heard Of
column15: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> Data scientists are responsible for breaking down big data into usable information and creating software and algorithms that help companies and organizations determine optimal operations.<ref name="":6"">{{Cite web
column17: title=How Data Science will Impact Future of Businesses?

column1: Data science and data analysis are both important disciplines in the field of [[data management]] and analysis, but they differ in several key ways. While both fields involve working with data, data science is more of an [[interdisciplinary field]] that involves the application of statistical, computational, and [[machine learning]] methods to extract insights from data and make predictions, while data analysis is more focused on the examination and interpretation of data to identify patterns and trends.<ref name="":8"">{{Cite book
column2: title=An Introduction to Statistical Learning: with Applications in R.
column19: title=Data Science for Business: What You Need to Know about Data Mining and Data-Analytic Thinking.

column1: Data analysis typically involves working with smaller, structured datasets to answer specific questions or solve specific problems. This can involve tasks such as [[data cleaning]], [[data visualization]], and exploratory data analysis to gain insights into the data and develop hypotheses about relationships between [[variable (research)
column2: variables]]. Data analysts typically use statistical methods to test these hypotheses and draw conclusions from the data. For example, a [[data analyst]] might analyze sales data to identify trends in customer behavior and make recommendations for marketing strategies.<ref name="":8"" />

column1: Data science, on the other hand, is a more complex and [[iterative]] process that involves working with larger, more complex datasets that often require advanced computational and statistical methods to analyze. Data scientists often work with [[unstructured data]] such as text or images and use [[machine learning]] algorithms to build predictive models and make data-driven decisions. In addition to [[statistical analysis]], data science often involves tasks such as [[data preprocessing]], [[feature engineering]], and model selection. For instance, a data scientist might develop a recommendation system for an e-commerce platform by analyzing user behavior patterns and using [[machine learning algorithms]] to predict user preferences.<ref name="":9"" /><ref name="":10"">{{Cite book

While data analysis focuses on extracting insights from existing data, data science goes beyond that by incorporating the development and implementation of predictive models to make informed decisions. Data scientists are often responsible for collecting and cleaning data, selecting appropriate analytical techniques, and deploying models in real-world scenarios. They work at the intersection of mathematics, [[computer science]], and [[domain expertise]] to solve complex problems and uncover hidden patterns in large datasets.<ref name="":9"" />
Despite these differences, data science and data analysis are closely related fields and often require similar skill sets. Both fields require a solid foundation in statistics, [[Computer programming
column2: programming]], and [[data visualization]], as well as the ability to communicate findings effectively to both technical and non-technical audiences. Both fields benefit from [[critical thinking]] and [[domain knowledge]], as understanding the context and nuances of the data is essential for accurate analysis and modeling.<ref name="":8"" /><ref name="":9"" />

column1: In summary, data analysis and data science are distinct yet interconnected disciplines within the broader field of [[data management]] and analysis. Data analysis focuses on extracting insights and drawing conclusions from [[structured data]], while data science involves a more comprehensive approach that combines [[statistical analysis]], computational methods, and [[machine learning]] to extract insights, build predictive models, and drive data-driven [[decision-making]]. Both fields use data to understand patterns, make informed decisions, and solve complex problems across various domains.
[[File:Cloud computing in enabling data science at scale.jpg
column3: A cloud-based architecture for enabling big data analytics. Data flows from various sources, such as [[Personal computer
column6: smart phones]], through cloud services for processing and analysis, finally leading to various [[big data]] applications.]]

column1: [[Cloud computing]] can offer access to large amounts of computational power and [[Data storage
column16: title=The rise of ""big data"" on cloud computing: Review and open research issues
column22: doi=10.1016/j.is.2014.07.006}}</ref> In [[big data]], where volumes of information are continually generated and processed, these platforms can be used to handle complex and resource-intensive analytical tasks.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite journal
column34: title=A survey of machine learning for big data processing
column35: journal=EURASIP Journal on Advances in Signal Processing

column1: Some distributed computing frameworks are designed to handle big data workloads. These frameworks can enable data scientists to process and analyze large datasets in parallel, which can reducing processing times.<ref name="":3"">{{Cite book
column24: chapter=Spark SQL: Relational Data Processing in Spark
column26: title=Proceedings of the 2015 ACM SIGMOD International Conference on Management of Data

column12: doi-access=free}}</ref> that uses [[statistics]], [[scientific computing]], [[scientific method]]s, processing, [[scientific visualization]], [[algorithm]]s and systems to extract or extrapolate [[knowledge]] and insights from potentially noisy, structured, or [[unstructured data]].<ref>{{Cite journal

column1: Data science also integrates domain knowledge from the underlying application domain (e.g., natural sciences, information technology, and medicine).<ref>{{cite report
column7: title=Computing Competencies for Undergraduate Data Science Curricula
column8: work=ACM Data Science Task Force Final Report
column9: url=https://dstf.acm.org/DSTF_Final_Report.pdf}}</ref> Data science is multifaceted and can be described as a science, a research paradigm, a research method, a discipline, a workflow, and a profession.<ref>{{Cite journal

column2: methods]]"" to ""understand and analyze actual [[phenomena]]"" with [[data]].<ref>{{Cite book

column1: Many statisticians, including [[Nate Silver]], have argued that data science is not a new field, but rather another name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Nate Silver: What I need from statisticians
column6: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> Others argue that data science is distinct from statistics because it focuses on problems and techniques unique to digital data.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=What's the Difference Between Data Science and Statistics?
column12: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> [[Vasant Dhar]] writes that statistics emphasizes quantitative data and description. In contrast, data science deals with quantitative and qualitative data (e.g., from images, text, sensors, transactions, customer information, etc.) and emphasizes prediction and action.<ref>{{Cite journal
column23: url=http://archive.nyu.edu/handle/2451/31553 }}</ref> [[Andrew Gelman]] of [[Columbia University]] has described statistics as a non-essential part of data science.<ref>{{Cite web
column25: title=Statistics is the least important part of data science Â« Statistical Modeling, Causal Inference, and Social Science

column1: Stanford professor [[David Donoho]] writes that data science is not distinguished from statistics by the size of datasets or use of computing and that many graduate programs misleadingly advertise their analytics and statistics training as the essence of a data-science program. He describes data science as an applied field growing out of traditional statistics.<ref name="":7"" />
In 1962, [[John Tukey]] described a field he called ""[[data analysis]]"", which resembles modern data science.<ref name="":7"">{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In 1985, in a lecture given to the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, [[C. F. Jeff Wu]] used the term ""data science"" for the first time as an alternative name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite journal
column9: title=Future directions of statistical research in China: a historical perspective
column16: access-date=29 November 2020}}</ref> Later, attendees at a 1992 statistics symposium at the [[Montpellier 2 University
column17: University of Montpellier  II]] acknowledged the emergence of a new discipline focused on data of various origins and forms, combining established concepts and principles of statistics and data analysis with computing.<ref>{{Cite book
column35: title=The Development of Data Science: Implications for Education, Employment, Research, and the Data Revolution for Sustainable Development

column1: The term ""data science"" has been traced back to 1974, when [[Peter Naur]] proposed it as an alternative name to computer science.<ref name="":2"" /> In 1996, the International Federation of Classification Societies became the first conference to specifically feature data science as a topic.<ref name="":2"" /> However, the definition was still in flux. After the 1985 lecture at the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, in 1997 [[C. F. Jeff Wu]] again suggested that statistics should be renamed data science. He reasoned that a new name would help statistics shed inaccurate stereotypes, such as being synonymous with accounting or limited to describing data.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In 1998, Hayashi Chikio argued for data science as a new, interdisciplinary concept, with three aspects: data design, collection, and analysis.<ref name=""Murtagh 2018 14""/>

column1: During the 1990s, popular terms for the process of finding patterns in datasets (which were increasingly large) included ""knowledge discovery"" and ""[[data mining]]"".<ref name="":2"" /><ref name="":1"">{{Cite web
column3: title=A Very Short History of Data Science

column1: In 2012, technologists [[Thomas H. Davenport]] and [[DJ Patil]] declared ""Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century"",<ref>{{cite magazine
column5: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
column8: access-date=2022-10-10}}</ref> a catchphrase that was picked up even by major-city newspapers like the [[New York Times]]<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Data Science: The Numbers of Our Lives
column20: title=Behind the scenes of the 'sexiest job of the 21st century'
column24: access-date=2022-10-10}}</ref> A decade later, they reaffirmed it, stating that ""the job is more in demand than ever with employers"".<ref>{{cite magazine
column28: title=Is Data Scientist Still the Sexiest Job of the 21st Century?

column1: The modern conception of data science as an independent discipline is sometimes attributed to [[William S. Cleveland]].<ref>{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In a 2001 paper, he advocated an expansion of statistics beyond theory into technical areas; because this would significantly change the field, it warranted a new name.<ref name="":1"" /> ""Data science"" became more widely used in the next few years: in 2002, the [[Committee on Data for Science and Technology]] launched the ''Data Science Journal''. In 2003, Columbia University launched ''The Journal of Data Science''.<ref name="":1"" /> In 2014, the [[American Statistical Association]]'s Section on Statistical Learning and Data Mining changed its name to the Section on Statistical Learning and Data Science, reflecting the ascendant popularity of data science.<ref>{{Cite news
column11: title=ASA Expands Scope, Outreach to Foster Growth, Collaboration in Data Science
column14: publisher=[[American Statistical Association]]}}. In 2013 the first European Conference on Data Analysis (ECDA2013) started in Luxembourg the process which founded the European Association for Data Science (EuADS) www.euads.org in Luxembourg in 2015. </ref>

column1: The professional title of ""data scientist"" has been attributed to [[DJ Patil]] and [[Jeff Hammerbacher]] in 2008.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
column12: issn=0017-8012}}</ref> Though it was used by the [[National Science Board]] in their 2005 report ""Long-Lived Digital Data Collections: Enabling Research and Education in the 21st Century"", it referred broadly to any key role in managing a digital [[data collection]].<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=US NSF â€“ NSB-05-40, Long-Lived Digital Data Collections Enabling Research and Education in the 21st Century

column1: There is still no consensus on the definition of data science, and it is considered by some to be a [[buzzword]].<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Data Science: What's The Half-Life of a Buzzword?
column8: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> [[Big data]] is a related marketing term.<ref name="":5"">{{Cite web
column10: title=The Impacts of Big Data That You May Not Have Heard Of
column15: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> Data scientists are responsible for breaking down big data into usable information and creating software and algorithms that help companies and organizations determine optimal operations.<ref name="":6"">{{Cite web
column17: title=How Data Science will Impact Future of Businesses?

column1: Data science and data analysis are both important disciplines in the field of [[data management]] and analysis, but they differ in several key ways. While both fields involve working with data, data science is more of an [[interdisciplinary field]] that involves the application of statistical, computational, and [[machine learning]] methods to extract insights from data and make predictions, while data analysis is more focused on the examination and interpretation of data to identify patterns and trends.<ref name="":8"">{{Cite book
column2: title=An Introduction to Statistical Learning: with Applications in R.
column19: title=Data Science for Business: What You Need to Know about Data Mining and Data-Analytic Thinking.

column1: Data analysis typically involves working with smaller, structured datasets to answer specific questions or solve specific problems. This can involve tasks such as [[data cleaning]], [[data visualization]], and exploratory data analysis to gain insights into the data and develop hypotheses about relationships between [[variable (research)
column2: variables]]. Data analysts typically use statistical methods to test these hypotheses and draw conclusions from the data. For example, a [[data analyst]] might analyze sales data to identify trends in customer behavior and make recommendations for marketing strategies.<ref name="":8"" />

column1: Data science, on the other hand, is a more complex and [[iterative]] process that involves working with larger, more complex datasets that often require advanced computational and statistical methods to analyze. Data scientists often work with [[unstructured data]] such as text or images and use [[machine learning]] algorithms to build predictive models and make data-driven decisions. In addition to [[statistical analysis]], data science often involves tasks such as [[data preprocessing]], [[feature engineering]], and model selection. For instance, a data scientist might develop a recommendation system for an e-commerce platform by analyzing user behavior patterns and using [[machine learning algorithms]] to predict user preferences.<ref name="":9"" /><ref name="":10"">{{Cite book

While data analysis focuses on extracting insights from existing data, data science goes beyond that by incorporating the development and implementation of predictive models to make informed decisions. Data scientists are often responsible for collecting and cleaning data, selecting appropriate analytical techniques, and deploying models in real-world scenarios. They work at the intersection of mathematics, [[computer science]], and [[domain expertise]] to solve complex problems and uncover hidden patterns in large datasets.<ref name="":9"" />
Despite these differences, data science and data analysis are closely related fields and often require similar skill sets. Both fields require a solid foundation in statistics, [[Computer programming
column2: programming]], and [[data visualization]], as well as the ability to communicate findings effectively to both technical and non-technical audiences. Both fields benefit from [[critical thinking]] and [[domain knowledge]], as understanding the context and nuances of the data is essential for accurate analysis and modeling.<ref name="":8"" /><ref name="":9"" />

column1: In summary, data analysis and data science are distinct yet interconnected disciplines within the broader field of [[data management]] and analysis. Data analysis focuses on extracting insights and drawing conclusions from [[structured data]], while data science involves a more comprehensive approach that combines [[statistical analysis]], computational methods, and [[machine learning]] to extract insights, build predictive models, and drive data-driven [[decision-making]]. Both fields use data to understand patterns, make informed decisions, and solve complex problems across various domains.
[[File:Cloud computing in enabling data science at scale.jpg
column3: A cloud-based architecture for enabling big data analytics. Data flows from various sources, such as [[Personal computer
column6: smart phones]], through cloud services for processing and analysis, finally leading to various [[big data]] applications.]]

column1: [[Cloud computing]] can offer access to large amounts of computational power and [[Data storage
column16: title=The rise of ""big data"" on cloud computing: Review and open research issues
column22: doi=10.1016/j.is.2014.07.006}}</ref> In [[big data]], where volumes of information are continually generated and processed, these platforms can be used to handle complex and resource-intensive analytical tasks.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite journal
column34: title=A survey of machine learning for big data processing
column35: journal=EURASIP Journal on Advances in Signal Processing

column1: Some distributed computing frameworks are designed to handle big data workloads. These frameworks can enable data scientists to process and analyze large datasets in parallel, which can reducing processing times.<ref name="":3"">{{Cite book
column24: chapter=Spark SQL: Relational Data Processing in Spark
column26: title=Proceedings of the 2015 ACM SIGMOD International Conference on Management of Data

column1: Data science involve collecting, processing, and analyzing data which often including personal and sensitive information. Ethical concerns include potential privacy violations, bias perpetuation, and negative societal impacts <ref name="":4"">{{Cite journal

column12: doi-access=free}}</ref> that uses [[statistics]], [[scientific computing]], [[scientific method]]s, processes, [[scientific visualization]], [[algorithm]]s and systems to extract or extrapolate [[knowledge]] and insights from potentially noisy, structured, or [[unstructured data]].<ref>{{Cite journal

column1: Data science also integrates domain knowledge from the underlying application domain (e.g., natural sciences, information technology, and medicine).<ref>{{cite report
column7: title=Computing Competencies for Undergraduate Data Science Curricula

column9: url=https://dstf.acm.org/DSTF_Final_Report.pdf}}</ref> Data science is multifaceted and can be described as a science, a research paradigm, a research method, a discipline, a workflow, and a profession.<ref>{{Cite journal

column1: Many statisticians, including [[Nate Silver]], have argued that data science is not a new field, but rather another name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Nate Silver: What I need from statisticians
column6: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> Others argue that data science is distinct from statistics because it focuses on problems and techniques unique to digital data.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=What's the Difference Between Data Science and Statistics?
column12: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> [[Vasant Dhar]] writes that statistics emphasizes quantitative data and description. In contrast, data science deals with quantitative and qualitative data (e.g., from images, text, sensors, transactions, customer information, etc.) and emphasizes prediction and action.<ref>{{Cite journal
column23: url=http://archive.nyu.edu/handle/2451/31553 }}</ref> [[Andrew Gelman]] of [[Columbia University]] has described statistics as a non-essential part of data science.<ref>{{Cite web
column25: title=Statistics is the least important part of data science Â« Statistical Modeling, Causal Inference, and Social Science

column1: Stanford professor [[David Donoho]] writes that data science is not distinguished from statistics by the size of datasets or use of computing and that many graduate programs misleadingly advertise their analytics and statistics training as the essence of a data-science program. He describes data science as an applied field growing out of traditional statistics.<ref name="":7"" />
In 1962, [[John Tukey]] described a field he called ""[[data analysis]]"", which resembles modern data science.<ref name="":7"">{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In 1985, in a lecture given to the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, [[C. F. Jeff Wu]] used the term ""data science"" for the first time as an alternative name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite journal
column9: title=Future directions of statistical research in China: a historical perspective
column16: access-date=29 November 2020}}</ref> Later, attendees at a 1992 statistics symposium at the [[Montpellier 2 University
column17: University of Montpellier  II]] acknowledged the emergence of a new discipline focused on data of various origins and forms, combining established concepts and principles of statistics and data analysis with computing.<ref>{{Cite book
column35: title=The Development of Data Science: Implications for Education, Employment, Research, and the Data Revolution for Sustainable Development

column1: The term ""data science"" has been traced back to 1974, when [[Peter Naur]] proposed it as an alternative name to computer science.<ref name="":2"" /> In 1996, the International Federation of Classification Societies became the first conference to specifically feature data science as a topic.<ref name="":2"" /> However, the definition was still in flux. After the 1985 lecture at the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, in 1997 [[C. F. Jeff Wu]] again suggested that statistics should be renamed data science. He reasoned that a new name would help statistics shed inaccurate stereotypes, such as being synonymous with accounting or limited to describing data.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In 1998, Hayashi Chikio argued for data science as a new, interdisciplinary concept, with three aspects: data design, collection, and analysis.<ref name=""Murtagh 2018 14""/>

column1: During the 1990s, popular terms for the process of finding patterns in datasets (which were increasingly large) included ""knowledge discovery"" and ""[[data mining]]"".<ref name="":2"" /><ref name="":1"">{{Cite web
column3: title=A Very Short History of Data Science

column1: In 2012, technologists [[Thomas H. Davenport]] and [[DJ Patil]] declared ""Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century"",<ref>{{cite magazine
column5: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
column8: access-date=2022-10-10}}</ref> a catchphrase that was picked up even by major-city newspapers like the [[New York Times]]<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Data Science: The Numbers of Our Lives
column20: title=Behind the scenes of the 'sexiest job of the 21st century'
column24: access-date=2022-10-10}}</ref> A decade later, they reaffirmed it, stating that ""the job is more in demand than ever with employers"".<ref>{{cite magazine
column28: title=Is Data Scientist Still the Sexiest Job of the 21st Century?

column1: The modern conception of data science as an independent discipline is sometimes attributed to [[William S. Cleveland]].<ref>{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In a 2001 paper, he advocated an expansion of statistics beyond theory into technical areas; because this would significantly change the field, it warranted a new name.<ref name="":1"" /> ""Data science"" became more widely used in the next few years: in 2002, the [[Committee on Data for Science and Technology]] launched the ''Data Science Journal''. In 2003, Columbia University launched ''The Journal of Data Science''.<ref name="":1"" /> In 2014, the [[American Statistical Association]]'s Section on Statistical Learning and Data Mining changed its name to the Section on Statistical Learning and Data Science, reflecting the ascendant popularity of data science.<ref>{{Cite news
column11: title=ASA Expands Scope, Outreach to Foster Growth, Collaboration in Data Science
column14: publisher=[[American Statistical Association]]}}. In 2013 the first European Conference on Data Analysis (ECDA2013) started in Luxembourg the process which founded the European Association for Data Science (EuADS) www.euads.org in Luxembourg in 2015. </ref>

column1: The professional title of ""data scientist"" has been attributed to [[DJ Patil]] and [[Jeff Hammerbacher]] in 2008.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
column12: issn=0017-8012}}</ref> Though it was used by the [[National Science Board]] in their 2005 report ""Long-Lived Digital Data Collections: Enabling Research and Education in the 21st Century"", it referred broadly to any key role in managing a digital [[data collection]].<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=US NSF â€“ NSB-05-40, Long-Lived Digital Data Collections Enabling Research and Education in the 21st Century

column1: There is still no consensus on the definition of data science, and it is considered by some to be a [[buzzword]].<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Data Science: What's The Half-Life of a Buzzword?
column8: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> [[Big data]] is a related marketing term.<ref name="":5"">{{Cite web
column10: title=The Impacts of Big Data That You May Not Have Heard Of
column15: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> Data scientists are responsible for breaking down big data into usable information and creating software and algorithms that help companies and organizations determine optimal operations.<ref name="":6"">{{Cite web
column17: title=How Data Science will Impact Future of Businesses?

column1: Data science and data analysis are both important disciplines in the field of [[data management]] and analysis, but they differ in several key ways. While both fields involve working with data, data science is more of an [[interdisciplinary field]] that involves the application of statistical, computational, and [[machine learning]] methods to extract insights from data and make predictions, while data analysis is more focused on the examination and interpretation of data to identify patterns and trends.<ref name="":8"">{{Cite book
column2: title=An Introduction to Statistical Learning: with Applications in R.
column19: title=Data Science for Business: What You Need to Know about Data Mining and Data-Analytic Thinking.

column1: Data analysis typically involves working with smaller, structured datasets to answer specific questions or solve specific problems. This can involve tasks such as [[data cleaning]], [[data visualization]], and exploratory data analysis to gain insights into the data and develop hypotheses about relationships between [[variable (research)
column2: variables]]. Data analysts typically use statistical methods to test these hypotheses and draw conclusions from the data. For example, a [[data analyst]] might analyze sales data to identify trends in customer behavior and make recommendations for marketing strategies.<ref name="":8"" />

column1: Data science, on the other hand, is a more complex and [[iterative]] process that involves working with larger, more complex datasets that often require advanced computational and statistical methods to analyze. Data scientists often work with [[unstructured data]] such as text or images and use [[machine learning]] algorithms to build predictive models and make data-driven decisions. In addition to [[statistical analysis]], data science often involves tasks such as [[data preprocessing]], [[feature engineering]], and model selection. For instance, a data scientist might develop a recommendation system for an e-commerce platform by analyzing user behavior patterns and using [[machine learning algorithms]] to predict user preferences.<ref name="":9"" /><ref name="":10"">{{Cite book

While data analysis focuses on extracting insights from existing data, data science goes beyond that by incorporating the development and implementation of predictive models to make informed decisions. Data scientists are often responsible for collecting and cleaning data, selecting appropriate analytical techniques, and deploying models in real-world scenarios. They work at the intersection of mathematics, [[computer science]], and [[domain expertise]] to solve complex problems and uncover hidden patterns in large datasets.<ref name="":9"" />
Despite these differences, data science and data analysis are closely related fields and often require similar skill sets. Both fields require a solid foundation in statistics, [[Computer programming
column2: programming]], and [[data visualization]], as well as the ability to communicate findings effectively to both technical and non-technical audiences. Both fields benefit from [[critical thinking]] and [[domain knowledge]], as understanding the context and nuances of the data is essential for accurate analysis and modeling.<ref name="":8"" /><ref name="":9"" />

column1: In summary, data analysis and data science are distinct yet interconnected disciplines within the broader field of [[data management]] and analysis. Data analysis focuses on extracting insights and drawing conclusions from [[structured data]], while data science involves a more comprehensive approach that combines [[statistical analysis]], computational methods, and [[machine learning]] to extract insights, build predictive models, and drive data-driven [[decision-making]]. Both fields use data to understand patterns, make informed decisions, and solve complex problems across various domains.
[[File:Cloud computing in enabling data science at scale.jpg
column3: A cloud-based architecture for enabling big data analytics. Data flows from various sources, such as [[Personal computer
column6: smart phones]], through cloud services for processing and analysis, finally leading to various [[big data]] applications.]]

column1: [[Cloud computing]] can offer access to large amounts of computational power and [[Data storage
column16: title=The rise of ""big data"" on cloud computing: Review and open research issues
column22: doi=10.1016/j.is.2014.07.006}}</ref> In [[big data]], where volumes of information are continually generated and processed, these platforms can be used to handle complex and resource-intensive analytical tasks.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite journal
column34: title=A survey of machine learning for big data processing
column35: journal=EURASIP Journal on Advances in Signal Processing

column1: Some distributed computing frameworks are designed to handle big data workloads. These frameworks can enable data scientists to process and analyze large datasets in parallel, which can reducing processing times.<ref name="":3"">{{Cite book
column24: chapter=Spark SQL: Relational Data Processing in Spark
column26: title=Proceedings of the 2015 ACM SIGMOD International Conference on Management of Data

column12: doi-access=free}}</ref> that uses [[statistics]], [[scientific computing]], [[scientific method]]s, processes, [[scientific visualization]], [[algorithm]]s and systems to extract or extrapolate [[knowledge]] and insights from potentially noisy, structured, or [[unstructured data]].<ref>{{Cite journal

column1: Data science also integrates domain knowledge from the underlying application domain (e.g., natural sciences, information technology, and medicine).<ref>{{cite report
column7: title=Computing Competencies for Undergraduate Data Science Curricula
column8: work=ACM Data Science Task Force Final Report
column9: url=https://dstf.acm.org/DSTF_Final_Report.pdf}}</ref> Data science is multifaceted and can be described as a science, a research paradigm, a research method, a discipline, a workflow, and a profession.<ref>{{Cite journal

column1: Data science is ""a concept to unify [[statistics]], [[data analysis]], [[informatics]], and their related [[Scientific method
column2: methods]]"" to ""understand and analyze actual [[phenomena]]"" with [[data]].<ref>{{Cite book
column4: title=Data Science, Classification, and Related Methods
column7: chapter=What is Data Science ? Fundamental Concepts and a Heuristic Example
column13: series=Studies in Classification, Data Analysis, and Knowledge Organization
column26: editor-first6=Yasumasa}}</ref> It uses techniques and theories drawn from many fields within the context of [[mathematics]], statistics, [[computer science]], [[information science]], and [[domain knowledge]].<ref name="":2"">{{Cite journal
column39: arxiv=2007.03606 }}</ref> However, data science is different from [[computer science]] and information science. [[Turing Award]] winner [[Jim Gray (computer scientist)
column40: Jim Gray]] imagined data science as a ""fourth paradigm"" of science ([[Empirical research
column43: computational]], and now data-driven) and asserted that ""everything about science is changing because of the impact of [[information technology]]"" and the [[information explosion

column48: title=The Fourth Paradigm: Data-intensive Scientific Discovery
column62: title=Computer Science: Beyond the Data Deluge

column1: A '''data scientist''' is a professional who creates programming code and combines it with statistical knowledge to create insights from data.<ref>{{Cite journal
column2: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century

column4: title=Defining data science by a data-driven quantification of the community
column16: large]] [[data set]]s and applying the knowledge and insights from that data to [[Problem-solving
column17: solve problems]] in a wide range of application domains. The field encompasses preparing data for analysis, formulating data science problems, [[Analysis
column18: analyzing]] data, developing data-driven solutions, and presenting findings to inform high-level decisions in a broad range of application domains. As such, it incorporates skills from computer science, statistics, information science, mathematics, [[data visualization]], [[information visualization]], [[data sonification]], data [[Data integration

column47: title=ASA Statement on the Role of Statistics in Data Science

column1: Many statisticians, including [[Nate Silver]], have argued that data science is not a new field, but rather another name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Nate Silver: What I need from statisticians
column6: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> Others argue that data science is distinct from statistics because it focuses on problems and techniques unique to digital data.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=What's the Difference Between Data Science and Statistics?
column12: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> [[Vasant Dhar]] writes that statistics emphasizes quantitative data and description. In contrast, data science deals with quantitative and qualitative data (e.g., from images, text, sensors, transactions, customer information, etc.) and emphasizes prediction and action.<ref>{{Cite journal
column23: url=http://archive.nyu.edu/handle/2451/31553 }}</ref> [[Andrew Gelman]] of [[Columbia University]] has described statistics as a non-essential part of data science.<ref>{{Cite web
column25: title=Statistics is the least important part of data science Â« Statistical Modeling, Causal Inference, and Social Science

column1: Stanford professor [[David Donoho]] writes that data science is not distinguished from statistics by the size of datasets or use of computing and that many graduate programs misleadingly advertise their analytics and statistics training as the essence of a data-science program. He describes data science as an applied field growing out of traditional statistics.<ref name="":7"" />
In 1962, [[John Tukey]] described a field he called ""[[data analysis]]"", which resembles modern data science.<ref name="":7"">{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In 1985, in a lecture given to the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, [[C. F. Jeff Wu]] used the term ""data science"" for the first time as an alternative name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite journal
column9: title=Future directions of statistical research in China: a historical perspective
column16: access-date=29 November 2020}}</ref> Later, attendees at a 1992 statistics symposium at the [[Montpellier 2 University
column17: University of Montpellier  II]] acknowledged the emergence of a new discipline focused on data of various origins and forms, combining established concepts and principles of statistics and data analysis with computing.<ref>{{Cite book
column35: title=The Development of Data Science: Implications for Education, Employment, Research, and the Data Revolution for Sustainable Development

column1: The term ""data science"" has been traced back to 1974, when [[Peter Naur]] proposed it as an alternative name to computer science.<ref name="":2"" /> In 1996, the International Federation of Classification Societies became the first conference to specifically feature data science as a topic.<ref name="":2"" /> However, the definition was still in flux. After the 1985 lecture at the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, in 1997 [[C. F. Jeff Wu]] again suggested that statistics should be renamed data science. He reasoned that a new name would help statistics shed inaccurate stereotypes, such as being synonymous with accounting or limited to describing data.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In 1998, Hayashi Chikio argued for data science as a new, interdisciplinary concept, with three aspects: data design, collection, and analysis.<ref name=""Murtagh 2018 14""/>

column1: During the 1990s, popular terms for the process of finding patterns in datasets (which were increasingly large) included ""knowledge discovery"" and ""[[data mining]]"".<ref name="":2"" /><ref name="":1"">{{Cite web
column3: title=A Very Short History of Data Science

column1: In 2012, technologists [[Thomas H. Davenport]] and [[DJ Patil]] declared ""Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century"",<ref>{{cite magazine
column5: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
column8: access-date=2022-10-10}}</ref> a catchphrase that was picked up even by major-city newspapers like the [[New York Times]]<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Data Science: The Numbers of Our Lives
column20: title=Behind the scenes of the 'sexiest job of the 21st century'
column24: access-date=2022-10-10}}</ref> A decade later, they reaffirmed it, stating that ""the job is more in demand than ever with employers"".<ref>{{cite magazine
column28: title=Is Data Scientist Still the Sexiest Job of the 21st Century?

column1: The modern conception of data science as an independent discipline is sometimes attributed to [[William S. Cleveland]].<ref>{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In a 2001 paper, he advocated an expansion of statistics beyond theory into technical areas; because this would significantly change the field, it warranted a new name.<ref name="":1"" /> ""Data science"" became more widely used in the next few years: in 2002, the [[Committee on Data for Science and Technology]] launched the ''Data Science Journal''. In 2003, Columbia University launched ''The Journal of Data Science''.<ref name="":1"" /> In 2014, the [[American Statistical Association]]'s Section on Statistical Learning and Data Mining changed its name to the Section on Statistical Learning and Data Science, reflecting the ascendant popularity of data science.<ref>{{Cite news
column11: title=ASA Expands Scope, Outreach to Foster Growth, Collaboration in Data Science
column14: publisher=[[American Statistical Association]]}}. In 2013 the first European Conference on Data Analysis (ECDA2013) started in Luxembourg the process which founded the European Association for Data Science (EuADS) www.euads.org in Luxembourg in 2015. </ref>

column1: The professional title of ""data scientist"" has been attributed to [[DJ Patil]] and [[Jeff Hammerbacher]] in 2008.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
column12: issn=0017-8012}}</ref> Though it was used by the [[National Science Board]] in their 2005 report ""Long-Lived Digital Data Collections: Enabling Research and Education in the 21st Century"", it referred broadly to any key role in managing a digital [[data collection]].<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=US NSF â€“ NSB-05-40, Long-Lived Digital Data Collections Enabling Research and Education in the 21st Century

column1: There is still no consensus on the definition of data science, and it is considered by some to be a [[buzzword]].<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Data Science: What's The Half-Life of a Buzzword?
column8: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> [[Big data]] is a related marketing term.<ref name="":5"">{{Cite web
column10: title=The Impacts of Big Data That You May Not Have Heard Of
column15: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> Data scientists are responsible for breaking down big data into usable information and creating software and algorithms that help companies and organizations determine optimal operations.<ref name="":6"">{{Cite web
column17: title=How Data Science will Impact Future of Businesses?

column2: alt=summary statistics and scatterplots showing the Datasaurus dozen data set
column4: Example for the usefulness of [[exploratory data analysis]] as demonstrated using the [[Datasaurus dozen]] data set]]

column1: Data science and data analysis are both important disciplines in the field of [[data management]] and analysis, but they differ in several key ways. While both fields involve working with data, data science is more of an [[interdisciplinary field]] that involves the application of statistical, computational, and [[machine learning]] methods to extract insights from data and make predictions, while data analysis is more focused on the examination and interpretation of data to identify patterns and trends.<ref name="":8"">{{Cite web
column3: title=An Introduction to Statistical Learning: with Applications in R.
column12: title=Data Science for Business: What You Need to Know about Data Mining and Data-Analytic Thinking.

column1: Data analysis typically involves working with smaller, structured datasets to answer specific questions or solve specific problems. This can involve tasks such as [[data cleaning]], [[data visualization]], and exploratory data analysis to gain insights into the data and develop hypotheses about relationships between [[variable (research)
column2: variables]]. Data analysts typically use statistical methods to test these hypotheses and draw conclusions from the data. For example, a [[data analyst]] might analyze sales data to identify trends in customer behavior and make recommendations for marketing strategies.<ref name="":8"" />

column1: Data science, on the other hand, is a more complex and [[iterative]] process that involves working with larger, more complex datasets that often require advanced computational and statistical methods to analyze. Data scientists often work with [[unstructured data]] such as text or images and use [[machine learning]] algorithms to build predictive models and make data-driven decisions. In addition to [[statistical analysis]], data science often involves tasks such as [[data preprocessing]], [[feature engineering]], and model selection. For instance, a data scientist might develop a recommendation system for an e-commerce platform by analyzing user behavior patterns and using [[machine learning algorithms]] to predict user preferences.<ref name="":9"" /><ref name="":10"">{{Cite book

While data analysis focuses on extracting insights from existing data, data science goes beyond that by incorporating the development and implementation of predictive models to make informed decisions. Data scientists are often responsible for collecting and cleaning data, selecting appropriate analytical techniques, and deploying models in real-world scenarios. They work at the intersection of mathematics, [[computer science]], and [[domain expertise]] to solve complex problems and uncover hidden patterns in large datasets.<ref name="":9"" />
Despite these differences, data science and data analysis are closely related fields and often require similar skill sets. Both fields require a solid foundation in statistics, [[Computer programming
column2: programming]], and [[data visualization]], as well as the ability to communicate findings effectively to both technical and non-technical audiences. Both fields benefit from [[critical thinking]] and [[domain knowledge]], as understanding the context and nuances of the data is essential for accurate analysis and modeling.<ref name="":8"" /><ref name="":9"" />

column1: In summary, data analysis and data science are distinct yet interconnected disciplines within the broader field of [[data management]] and analysis. Data analysis focuses on extracting insights and drawing conclusions from [[structured data]], while data science involves a more comprehensive approach that combines [[statistical analysis]], computational methods, and [[machine learning]] to extract insights, build predictive models, and drive data-driven [[decision-making]]. Both fields use data to understand patterns, make informed decisions, and solve complex problems across various domains.
[[File:Cloud computing in enabling data science at scale.jpg
column3: A cloud-based architecture for enabling big data analytics. Data flows from various sources, such as [[Personal computer
column6: smart phones]], through cloud services for processing and analysis, finally leading to various [[big data]] applications.]]

column1: [[Cloud computing]] can offer access to large amounts of computational power and [[Data storage
column16: title=The rise of ""big data"" on cloud computing: Review and open research issues
column22: doi=10.1016/j.is.2014.07.006}}</ref> In [[big data]], where volumes of information are continually generated and processed, these platforms can be used to handle complex and resource-intensive analytical tasks.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite journal
column34: title=A survey of machine learning for big data processing
column35: journal=EURASIP Journal on Advances in Signal Processing

column1: Some distributed computing frameworks are designed to handle big data workloads. These frameworks can enable data scientists to process and analyze large datasets in parallel, which can reducing processing times.<ref name="":3"">{{Cite book
column24: chapter=Spark SQL: Relational Data Processing in Spark
column26: title=Proceedings of the 2015 ACM SIGMOD International Conference on Management of Data

column1: Data science involve collecting, processing, and analyzing data which often including personal and sensitive information. Ethical concerns include potential privacy violations, bias perpetuation, and negative societal impacts <ref name="":4"">{{Cite journal
column8: journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
column23: title=The Ethics of Big Data: Current and Foreseeable Issues in Biomedical Contexts

column1: Machine learning models can amplify existing biases present in training data, leading to discriminatory or unfair outcomes.<ref>{{Cite journal

column1: Many statisticians, including [[Nate Silver]], have argued that data science is not a new field, but rather another name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Nate Silver: What I need from statisticians
column6: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> Others argue that data science is distinct from statistics because it focuses on problems and techniques unique to digital data.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=What's the Difference Between Data Science and Statistics?
column12: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> [[Vasant Dhar]] writes that statistics emphasizes quantitative data and description. In contrast, data science deals with quantitative and qualitative data (e.g., from images, text, sensors, transactions, customer information, etc.) and emphasizes prediction and action.<ref>{{Cite journal
column23: url=http://archive.nyu.edu/handle/2451/31553 }}</ref> [[Andrew Gelman]] of [[Columbia University]] has described statistics as a non-essential part of data science.<ref>{{Cite web
column25: title=Statistics is the least important part of data science Â« Statistical Modeling, Causal Inference, and Social Science

column1: Stanford professor [[David Donoho]] writes that data science is not distinguished from statistics by the size of datasets or use of computing and that many graduate programs misleadingly advertise their analytics and statistics training as the essence of a data-science program. He describes data science as an applied field growing out of traditional statistics.<ref name="":7"" />
In 1962, [[John Tukey]] described a field he called ""[[data analysis]]"", which resembles modern data science.<ref name="":7"">{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In 1985, in a lecture given to the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, [[C. F. Jeff Wu]] used the term ""data science"" for the first time as an alternative name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite journal
column9: title=Future directions of statistical research in China: a historical perspective
column16: access-date=29 November 2020}}</ref> Later, attendees at a 1992 statistics symposium at the [[Montpellier 2 University
column17: University of Montpellier  II]] acknowledged the emergence of a new discipline focused on data of various origins and forms, combining established concepts and principles of statistics and data analysis with computing.<ref>{{Cite book
column35: title=The Development of Data Science: Implications for Education, Employment, Research, and the Data Revolution for Sustainable Development

column1: The term ""data science"" has been traced back to 1974, when [[Peter Naur]] proposed it as an alternative name to computer science.<ref name="":2"" /> In 1996, the International Federation of Classification Societies became the first conference to specifically feature data science as a topic.<ref name="":2"" /> However, the definition was still in flux. After the 1985 lecture at the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, in 1997 [[C. F. Jeff Wu]] again suggested that statistics should be renamed data science. He reasoned that a new name would help statistics shed inaccurate stereotypes, such as being synonymous with accounting or limited to describing data.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In 1998, Hayashi Chikio argued for data science as a new, interdisciplinary concept, with three aspects: data design, collection, and analysis.<ref name=""Murtagh 2018 14""/>

column1: During the 1990s, popular terms for the process of finding patterns in datasets (which were increasingly large) included ""knowledge discovery"" and ""[[data mining]]"".<ref name="":2"" /><ref name="":1"">{{Cite web
column3: title=A Very Short History of Data Science

column1: In 2012, technologists [[Thomas H. Davenport]] and [[DJ Patil]] declared ""Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century"",<ref>{{cite magazine
column5: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
column8: access-date=2022-10-10}}</ref> a catchphrase that was picked up even by major-city newspapers like the [[New York Times]]<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Data Science: The Numbers of Our Lives
column20: title=Behind the scenes of the 'sexiest job of the 21st century'
column24: access-date=2022-10-10}}</ref> A decade later, they reaffirmed it, stating that ""the job is more in demand than ever with employers"".<ref>{{cite magazine
column28: title=Is Data Scientist Still the Sexiest Job of the 21st Century?

column1: The modern conception of data science as an independent discipline is sometimes attributed to [[William S. Cleveland]].<ref>{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2 April 2020}}</ref> In a 2001 paper, he advocated an expansion of statistics beyond theory into technical areas; because this would significantly change the field, it warranted a new name.<ref name="":1"" /> ""Data science"" became more widely used in the next few years: in 2002, the [[Committee on Data for Science and Technology]] launched the ''Data Science Journal''. In 2003, Columbia University launched ''The Journal of Data Science''.<ref name="":1"" /> In 2014, the [[American Statistical Association]]'s Section on Statistical Learning and Data Mining changed its name to the Section on Statistical Learning and Data Science, reflecting the ascendant popularity of data science.<ref>{{Cite news
column11: title=ASA Expands Scope, Outreach to Foster Growth, Collaboration in Data Science
column14: publisher=[[American Statistical Association]]}}. In 2013 the first European Conference on Data Analysis (ECDA2013) started in Luxembourg the process which founded the European Association for Data Science (EuADS) www.euads.org in Luxembourg in 2015. </ref>

column1: The professional title of ""data scientist"" has been attributed to [[DJ Patil]] and [[Jeff Hammerbacher]] in 2008.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
column12: issn=0017-8012}}</ref> Though it was used by the [[National Science Board]] in their 2005 report ""Long-Lived Digital Data Collections: Enabling Research and Education in the 21st Century"", it referred broadly to any key role in managing a digital [[data collection]].<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=US NSF â€“ NSB-05-40, Long-Lived Digital Data Collections Enabling Research and Education in the 21st Century

column15: access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> Data scientists are responsible for breaking down big data into usable information and creating software and algorithms that help companies and organizations determine optimal operations.<ref name="":6"">{{Cite web

column1: Data science and data analysis are both important disciplines in the field of [[data management]] and analysis, but they differ in several key ways. While both fields involve working with data, data science is more of an [[interdisciplinary field]] that involves the application of statistical, computational, and [[machine learning]] methods to extract insights from data and make predictions, while data analysis is more focused on the examination and interpretation of data to identify patterns and trends.<ref name="":8"">{{Cite web
column3: title=An Introduction to Statistical Learning: with Applications in R.
column12: title=Data Science for Business: What You Need to Know about Data Mining and Data-Analytic Thinking.

column1: Data analysis typically involves working with smaller, structured datasets to answer specific questions or solve specific problems. This can involve tasks such as [[data cleaning]], [[data visualization]], and exploratory data analysis to gain insights into the data and develop hypotheses about relationships between [[variable (research)
column2: variables]]. Data analysts typically use statistical methods to test these hypotheses and draw conclusions from the data. For example, a [[data analyst]] might analyze sales data to identify trends in customer behavior and make recommendations for marketing strategies.<ref name="":8"" />

column1: Data science, on the other hand, is a more complex and [[iterative]] process that involves working with larger, more complex datasets that often require advanced computational and statistical methods to analyze. Data scientists often work with [[unstructured data]] such as text or images and use [[machine learning]] algorithms to build predictive models and make data-driven decisions. In addition to [[statistical analysis]], data science often involves tasks such as [[data preprocessing]], [[feature engineering]], and model selection. For instance, a data scientist might develop a recommendation system for an e-commerce platform by analyzing user behavior patterns and using [[machine learning algorithms]] to predict user preferences.<ref name="":9"" /><ref name="":10"">{{Cite book

While data analysis focuses on extracting insights from existing data, data science goes beyond that by incorporating the development and implementation of predictive models to make informed decisions. Data scientists are often responsible for collecting and cleaning data, selecting appropriate analytical techniques, and deploying models in real-world scenarios. They work at the intersection of mathematics, [[computer science]], and [[domain expertise]] to solve complex problems and uncover hidden patterns in large datasets.<ref name="":9"" />
Despite these differences, data science and data analysis are closely related fields and often require similar skill sets. Both fields require a solid foundation in statistics, [[Computer programming
column2: programming]], and [[data visualization]], as well as the ability to communicate findings effectively to both technical and non-technical audiences. Both fields benefit from [[critical thinking]] and [[domain knowledge]], as understanding the context and nuances of the data is essential for accurate analysis and modeling.<ref name="":8"" /><ref name="":9"" />

column1: In summary, data analysis and data science are distinct yet interconnected disciplines within the broader field of [[data management]] and analysis. Data analysis focuses on extracting insights and drawing conclusions from [[structured data]], while data science involves a more comprehensive approach that combines [[statistical analysis]], computational methods, and [[machine learning]] to extract insights, build predictive models, and drive data-driven [[decision-making]]. Both fields use data to understand patterns, make informed decisions, and solve complex problems across various domains.
[[File:Cloud computing in enabling data science at scale.jpg
column3: A cloud-based architecture for enabling big data analytics. Data flows from various sources, such as [[Personal computer
column6: smart phones]], through cloud services for processing and analysis, finally leading to various [[big data]] applications.]]

column22: doi=10.1016/j.is.2014.07.006}}</ref> In [[big data]], where volumes of information are continually generated and processed, these platforms can be used to handle complex and resource-intensive analytical tasks.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite journal
column34: title=A survey of machine learning for big data processing
column35: journal=EURASIP Journal on Advances in Signal Processing

column1: Many statisticians, including [[Nate Silver]], have argued that data science is not a new field, but rather another name for statistics.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Nate Silver: What I need from statisticians

In contrast, data science deals with quantitative and qualitative data (e.g., from images, text, sensors, transactions, customer information, etc.) and emphasizes prediction and action.<ref>{{Cite journal
column23: url=http://archive.nyu.edu/handle/2451/31553 }}</ref> [[Andrew Gelman]] of [[Columbia University]] has described statistics as a non-essential part of data science.<ref>{{Cite web
